This is a consequence of how objectForKey works. Integers, doubles and booleans are all encoded as NSNumber. There is no API to check for user defaults type (it is held _somewhere_, as you can see by trying `defaults read-type ...`, but it's not exposed to NSUserDefaults).

So, 100 == true, and 0 == false, because that's what NSNumber does.

If you'd like to check for a `BOOL` in `NSNumber`, there're two ways ...
1. Compare `[NSNumber objCType]` with `@encode(BOOL)`
2. Get number type via `CFNumberType numberType = CFNumberGetType((CFNumberRef)someNSNumber)`, `BOOL` is `kCFNumberCharType`

Does it work reliably though? The last time I looked into this, NSNumber did _not_ promise (at all) that the representation of booleans would be explicitly as booleans. It just thought it's the same as ints…

Did work when I was playing with it. But documentation says this:

> If you ask a number for its objCType, however, the returned type does not necessarily match the method the receiver was created with.

Which means that we have no clue what's going on internally and it can be whatever anytime Apple decides to change it.

In other words, there's no reliable and 100% working way to do this unless you would like to break compatibility (replacing SwiftyUserDefaults with something else). I mean, you can encode types by adding some prefix to keys internally, checking these prefixes when getting values back or storing custom data. But it's not worth it IMHO unless you would like to achieve - when I store anything other then Bool, I can't get back true under any circumstances, always false.
Hm. It's super annoying, though, because internally, defaults does store the type — it's just that NSNumber doesn't, and AFAIK there's no API to check for key's type :(

Can you elaborate on the `?=` problem you're describing? `?=` shouldn't be used with `nil` — it just doesn't make sense to assign a `nil` to something when it's `nil`…

If assigning a variable whose type is Any  with an optional value, the variable cannot be converted to the original value. For example:

``` swift
var a: String? = "abc"
var b: Any = a
if let v = b as? String {
    println("b is String")
} else {
    println("b is not String")
}
```

"b is not String" is printed.

So, if I put an optional value after ?= operator, the value will be considered invalid. That is confused.
For example, write something like this:

``` swift
let string: String? = "abc"
Defaults["string"] ?= string
```

`assertionFailure("Invalid value type")` will be triggered.
That sounds like a Swift bug. Have you filed a radar?

Actually this looks like a dup of #40. Would be interested to hear your arguments for a subscripting approach.

A few reasons:
1. Syntax. I like the dictionary-like feel of `Defaults[.prop]` vs `Defaults.prop.value`.
2. And it's a little bit shorter
3. And that it feels like it makes a bit more sense with you subscripting a collection, not calling "value" on the key itself
4. If you're not using the standard user defaults, but some other NSUserDefaults (e.g. shared defaults in an app group), you can just subscript a different defaults object — the key object only describes the key, not the collection

Yeah, it's kind of an implementation PITA, but I'm not concerned with that in this project — it's not an approach I would usually take, but I slightly prefer this approach to what you're suggesting. I'm cool with magic.

Hm. Lack of support for floats was a deliberate decision -- Swift strongly recommends just using Double everywhere. The fact that UISlider reports Float -- I consider that an interop limitation.
Oh, that's a surprise. I'd have thought for mobile Apple would've encouraged float for memory efficiency when precision wasn't needed. Never mind then.

Nope. Swift encourages people to just use Int and Double. Float is great when you **need** the efficiency — that is, when you have significant arrays of them (SCNVector3 is probably a good use case, I think). Otherwise, it just doesn't matter.

I think it'd be handy to set global `suiteName` once, somewhere early (e.g.  in `AppDelegate`):
`Defaults.suiteName = "group.my.appGroup"`

And all consecutive calls to `Defaults` would then return `NSUserDefaults` object created for this specific suite. From my experience, you rarely need to keep multiple different sets of user defaults (and when you want that, @radex's method of introducing another global variable is probably the best). 

But for most use cases (e.g. sharing Defaults with app extensions), I believe juggling with two different Defaults objects is suboptimal because it's possible to end up with wrong defaults object which may be a source of obscure bugs.

A technical note, I don't think this would be possible without subclassing `NSUserDefaults` which is not as elegant as having `Defaults` as a global variable and _may_ introduce a set of other issues.

Similarly, `Defaults.synchronizeOnChange = true/false` would be awesome. Calling synchronize on every change all the time may introduce performance issues in certain cases because it actually saves to disk behind the scenes. But when you run in the debug mode or in the app extension, you may loose data saved to defaults unless you manually call `Defaults.synchronize()` each time you change something because the system may kill the process suddenly, to the best of my understanding (and in the case of running from Xcode, if you stop the project just at the right time, it won't save either). 

So, giving this option to the user would be more elegant than synchronizing manually.

> I think it'd be handy to set global suiteName once, somewhere early (e.g. in AppDelegate):
> Defaults.suiteName = "group.my.appGroup"

I'd much prefer the declarative version:

```
var Defaults = NSUserDefaults(suiteName: ...)
```

This is cleaner to me, and has the advantage that you can put it in a separate file you can share between targets...

>  you may loose data saved to defaults unless you manually call Defaults.synchronize() each time you change something because the system may kill the process suddenly, to the best of my understanding (and in the case of running from Xcode, if you stop the project just at the right time, it won't save either).

So I've been thinking about how to actually implement this statically-typed defaults dictionary.

Now, we can't actually do it as a dictionary, because we need the requirement for the value to be T matching key's DefaultsKey<T> AND the ability to have key/value pairs of different types. There's no way to express that in Swift.

You could do it as tuples, i.e. `[ (.userName, "radex"), (.launchCount, 0) ]`, but that would make the array `[(DefaultsKeys, Any)]`, an there's no compile-time type check. Sigh.

So I have two concepts that might be possible to implement.

One would be a builder DSL:

```
registerDefaults(.userName, "radex")
    .and(.launchCount, 10)
    .and(.this, that)
```

`registerDefaults()` would be `<T>(DefaultsKey<T>, T)`, and would return something like `DefaultsBuilder`, which would have a method `and` with the same signature.

Another option would be something like:

```
registerDefaults([
    .key(.userName, "radex"),
    .key(.launchCount, 10),
])
```

registerDefaults would take an array of `DefaultsKeyValue` (name tbd), which would have a static func `key` (also looking for a better name) — essentially a factory method returning the same type. The method would be `<T>(DefaultsKey<T>, T)` to type-check the passed stuff.

Not super in love with either concept. Do you have better ideas?

Maybe some kind of builder?

``` swift
registerDefaults { set in
    set(.userName, "radex")
    set(.launchCount, 10)
}

registerDefaults {
    $0[.userName] = "radex"
    $0[.launchCount] += 1
}
```

Actually just realized registering defaults in a global `var Defaults = ...` has the same issue — it will be evaluated lazily :(

Ideas? If applicationFinishedLaunching... isn't a good place to do it, then perhaps init is?

I want to avoid changing the API of `UserDefaults.Proxy` because I consider it a legacy API — and I strongly want to encourage people to use the new, static key-based API. I agree as far as Swift 2/3 compatibility is concerned. The shipping version of SwiftyUserDefaults compiles just fine with Swift 2.3, so people can keep using that for as long as they need. Next version will be Swift 3-only.

Hey @lagoman88. So I've researched the topic and here are the main points:
1. When setting up the launch arguments (either using `launchArguments` property or using arguments in the scheme editor), all of the arguments are `Strings`.
1. `Bool` is working only because `bool(forKey:)` is specific. It treats both `YES` or `1` as a positive values, because of `Objective-C` legacy. Thus, in this case, it seems like a hack rather than a fix. For instance `Int` wouldn't work, still.
1. I think @radex used `object(forKey:)` instead of `bool(forKey:)` also because of that - it doesn't force a default value and do not do any magic under the hood. This will be helpful if we introduce setting up default values by yourself.
1. If we change this method now, someone that relies on only getting classic bool values instead of strings would get a false positive because with an edge case he would get a `true` value for a ` YES` string.

Because all of that I'm more likely to keep it as it is now, but I'm eager to hear what is your opinion on what I've gathered.

> I think @radex used object(forKey:) instead of bool(forKey:) also because of that - it doesn't force a default value and do not do any magic under the hood.

If you used dedicated `string(forKey:)` for `String` subscripts, `numberForKey(forKey:)` for `Int`s and `Double`s, `data(forKey:)` for `Data` or `url(forKey:)` for `URL`, why wouldn't you use `bool(forKey:)` for `Bool`s? This method is dedicated for this type.

Hey @lagoman88. Let's break down this problem into two smaller pieces.

1. When you add a launch argument to the project, it sets the `UserDefault` using a `String`.  So even though you want to get this key as a `Bool` afterwards, it works by an accident.
2. `bool(forKey:)` is really specific, as is `integer(forKey:)` or `float(forKey:)` - all of these return a default value that is given to use by `Apple`. That's why all of these are not used in the project and that's why `number(forKey:)` is used instead.

So why does this combination with launch arguments and `bool(forKey:)` works as an accident? Because of the `ObjC` legacy and the fact that `"YES"` or `"NO"` are valid `Bool` values in `ObjC`.

It's false positive in a sense that if you save a `String` and want a `Bool` instead - it shouldn't really be possible under statically-types Swift. 

Additionally, using `bool(forKey:)` and friends we would make it harder to update to custom default values in the future because there would be a layer of default values provided by Apple themselves.

Hey guys! So this week I'm planning to show you the first preview of the `4.0.0-alpha` version! Currently, I have a working copy of the next version - all of the features I listed are in, but with some rough code in it. Let's hope that all of these will work after the cleanup 😉 The update took longer than expected because of the `Codable` support with the default values and generic subscripts with statically typed initializers altogether. It was really not easy to come up with the solution that had it all. Basically, we can't really extend `Codable` to implement a certain protocol. This way we would have to think about a way of creating a `DefaultsKey` from two different protocols (or even better, for `Codable`, `DefaultSerializable` - which is a custom way of storing/getting the value from `UserDefaults` and `Codable & DefaultsSerializable` at once). And I didn't want to make a big migration, but rather keep the existing functionality and add on top of that. Thus, the solution I came up with was to use two classes for `DefaultsKey`: `DefaultsKey`, the backwards-compatible version that you use today, and `DefaultsCodableKey`, a class specialized for `Codable` serializing. There will be some additional protocols so you can extend any type you want to have a `defaultValue` or fetch/store a value to `UserDefaults` your way. See all the new options are in the screen below. Personally, I love that when you want to initialize a key without a default value either by parameter or a type, you'll get an instant error about it 😉 _* Note: All the protocol names are WIP, might change in the future._

I experienced the same issue and manually specifying the defaultValue of nil did fix it. But digging into it I'm not sure why that's the case.

Without specifying the defaultValue, the convenience init should be calling the private init which sets the defaultValue to nil
```
    private init(key: String) {
        self._key = key
        self.defaultValue = nil
    }
```

so functionally both inits should be equivalent.

Further, the subscript function uses the nil coalescing operator to run through possible return values
```
return T.get(key: key._key, userDefaults: self) ?? key.defaultValue ?? T.defaultValue
```

the `T.defaultValue` is the blank string defined in the String extension
```
extension String: DefaultsSerializable, DefaultsDefaultArrayValueType, DefaultsDefaultValueType {

    public static var defaultValue: String = ""
```

So I'm not sure why the nil coalescing would ever return the specified nil defaultValue instead of the empty string.

This is not a bug in ``SwiftyUserDefaults`` but rather a default behavior of underlying ``UserDefaults`` which do save settings only at certain times in the lifecycle of the app. Typically reruning the app from Xcode will kill it without giving it any chance to persist the settings to the permanent storage.

If you want to make sure settings are stored immediately there is a method ``UserDefaults.standard.synchronize()`` IIRC.

Not sure if SwiftyUserDefaults provides interface for this.
Okay makes sense - thanks.

Hey @fredpi! Glad you figured it out and that it works as expected - I'm happy that the current system is capable of doing something like that, it feels powerful. 

So the `Codable` array issue. If you look at the array bridge for `Codable` it's basically the same class as for a single value bridge. This is because an array of `Codable` values is a `Codable` itself!

And, as you probably know, `Codable` is first serialized into `Data` and then saved to the property list that `UserDefaults` uses underneath the public API layer. This is the reason why it didn't work for you - you had an array of data values saved into property list instead of one data blob that can be deserialized into an array.

Also, great job on the custom array bridge! One thing to note is that you should implement `isSerialized` and `deserialize` methods if you want to use KVO in the future with your types.

And yeah I agree, we could not only make `set(encodable:)` but also probably make all the bridges we have in the library `open` instead of `public` to make it easier to create custom bridges. If you would like to make a PR with given updates I would be really grateful!
